column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|label
#T_RL=custom.Relation|label|BT_custom.Span
#Text=Grooms and Hostlers daily inhale a large quantity of ammoniacal gas generated in the stables.
#Text=This appears beneficial rather than injurious.
#Text=They
#Text=have, moreover, full and varied muscular exertion ;
#Text=and if they took a more moderate diet, would be almost universally robust.
#Text=Hostlers, Porters, and
#Text=under-male servants at inns, are generally sickly,
#Text=
#Text=and labour under congestion (over fulness) of the vessels in the abdomen and head.
#Text=Their state evidently
#Text=results from the ale and spirits they take so frequently.
#Text=Glue and Size boilers are exposed to strong putrid and ammoniacal exhalations from the decomposition of animal refuse.
#Text=The stench of the boiling
#Text=and drying rooms is indeed well known to be highly
#Text=offensive, even to the neighbourhood.
#Text=Yet the men
#Text=declare it agrees well with them — nay, many assert,
#Text=that on entering this employ, they experienced a
#Text=great increase of appetite and health.
#Text=All the glue
#Text=and size boilers we saw, were remarkably fresh-looking and robust.
#Text=Though exposed to frequent and
#Text=considerable changes of temperature, to sudden
#Text=changes also from an atmosphere of hot vapour to
#Text=the dry cold air, they are not subject to rheumatism,
#Text=pulmonary inflammation or catarrh.
#Text=The only complaints we could hear of, were occasional pains in the
#Text=loins and hmbs, attributable to posture and exertion.
#Text=Buckram manufacturers are exposed to the
#Text=odour of the glue.
#Text=This is well known to be so great
#Text=as to offend the neighbourhood of the manufacture.
#Text=Yet the men make no complaint of ill health, and
#Text=reach considerable age.
#Text=Of the seven men employed
#Text=at the Buckram-house, in Water-lane, one is 51,
#Text=another 58, a third 68, and the fourth 76; and these
#Text=individuals have been at the employ from an early age.
#Text=Tallow-chandlers, subjected to an offensive
#Text=animal odour, enjoy health, and attain a considerable
#Text=age.
#Text=During the plague in London it was remarked
#Text=that this class of men suffered much less than others.
#Text=Tanners, it is well known, arc subject to disagreeable odours.
#Text=They work in an atmosphere largely
#Text=impregnated with the vapour of putrifying skins, and
#Text=this combined with the smell of lime in one place,
#Text=and of tan in another.
#Text=They are exposed constantly
#Text=to wet and cold.
#Text=Their feet are scarcely ever dry.
#Text=Yet they are remarkably robust; the countenance
#Text=florid ; and disease almost unknown. t Tanners are
#Text=said to be exempt from consumption ; and the subject
#Text=has of late been repeatedly discussed in one of the
#Text=medical societies of London.
#Text=We have carefully inquired at several tan-yards, and could not hear of a
#Text=single example of this formidable disease.
#Text=We do
#Text=not find old men actually in the employ; and the
#Text=reason assigned is, not the decline of health, but the
#Text=inferiority of men past middle age, in undergoing the
#Text=labour of the process.
#Text=Persons however in advanced
#Text=life, yet healthy, are found in other occupations, who
#Text=have before been for many years in the tan-yards,
#Text=and have not apparently suffered from the long continued exposure to their offensive odour.
#Text=Hence we
#Text=may infer that this employ, while it invigorates the
#Text=constitution in youth and middle age, does not sensibly shorten life ; does not, in other words, give temporary health at the expense of premature decline.
#Text=Ramazzini tells us, that at Padua the tan-yards
#Text=were permitted only in the  '  suburbs.
#Text=Here also, as
#Text=the stench would be considered a nuisance, tan-yards
#Text=are at the outskirts.
#Text=As a matter of medical police,
#Text=however, we see no occasion for their exclusion from
#Text=the town.
